title: Computing the Largest Bond and the Maximum Connected Cut of a Graph This work is partially supported by JST CREST JPMJCR1401, and JSPS KAKENHI grant numbers JP17H01788, JP16K16010, JP17K19960, and JP19K21537, and by SÃ£o Paulo Research Foundation (FAPESP) grant number 2015/11937-9, and Rio de Janeiro Research Foundation (FAPERJ) grant number E-26/203.272/2017, and by National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq-Brazil) grant numbers 308689/2017-8, 425340/2016-3, 313026/2017-3, 422829/2018-8, 303726/2017-2. The Japanese authors thank Akitoshi Kawamura and Yukiko Yamauchi for giving an opportunity to discuss in the Open Problem Seminar in Kyushu University, Japan. Preliminary versions of this paper appeared in [27] and [22].

sections.introduction:
Let G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be a simple, connected, undirected graph. A disconnecting set of GğºG is a set of edges FâŠ†Eâ€‹(G)ğ¹ğ¸ğºF\subseteq E(G) whose removal disconnects GğºG. The edge-connectivity of GğºG is Îºâ€²â€‹(G)=minâ¡{|F|:FÂ is a disconnecting set ofÂ G}superscriptğœ…â€²ğº:ğ¹FÂ is a disconnecting set ofÂ G\kappa^{\prime}(G)=\min\{|F|:\mbox{$F$ is a disconnecting set of $G$}\}. A cut [S,T]ğ‘†ğ‘‡[S,T] of GğºG is a partition of Vğ‘‰V into two subsets Sğ‘†S and T=Vâˆ–Sğ‘‡ğ‘‰ğ‘†T=V\setminus S. The cut-set âˆ‚(S)ğ‘†\partial(S) of a cut [S,T]ğ‘†ğ‘‡[S,T] is the set of edges that have one endpoint in Sğ‘†S and the other endpoint in Tğ‘‡T; these edges are said to cross the cut. In a connected graph, each cut-set determines a unique cut.
Note that every cut-set is a disconnecting set, but the converse is not true.
An inclusion-wise minimal disconnecting set of a graph is called a bond (or a minimal cut). It is easy to see that every bond is a cut-set, but there are cut-sets that are not bonds. More precisely, a nonempty set of edges Fğ¹F of GğºG is a bond if and only if Fğ¹F determines a cut [S,T]ğ‘†ğ‘‡[S,T] of GğºG such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] and Gâ€‹[T]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‡G[T] are both connected. LetÂ s,tâˆˆVâ€‹(G)ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰ğºs,t\in V(G). An sâ€‹tğ‘ ğ‘¡st-bond of GğºG is a bond whose removal disconnects sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t. A minimum (maximum) cut of a graph GğºG is a cut with cut-set of minimum (maximum) size. Every minimum cut is a bond, thus a minimum bond is also a minimum cut of GğºG, and it can be found in polynomial time using the classical Edmondsâ€“Karp algorithmÂ . Besides that, minimum sâ€‹tğ‘ ğ‘¡st-bonds are well-known structures, since they are precisely the sâ€‹tğ‘ ğ‘¡st-cuts involved in the Gomory-Hu treesÂ . Maximum Cut is one of the most fundamental problems in theoretical computer science. Given a graph GğºG and an integer kğ‘˜k, the problem asks for a subset Sğ‘†S of vertices such that |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k. Whenever the subgraph of GğºG induced by Sğ‘†S is connected, the cut [S,Vâˆ–S]ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğ‘†[S,V\setminus S] is called connected. Recall that every bond is a connected cut, but the converse is not true. In this paper, we are interested in the complexity aspects of the following problem. 


Maximum Connected Cut
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E); a positive integer kğ‘˜k.
Question: Is there a proper subset SâŠ‚Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºS\subset V(G) such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] is connected and |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k?

 


Largest Bond
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E); a positive integer kğ‘˜k.
Question: Is there a proper subset SâŠ‚Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºS\subset V(G) such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] and Gâ€‹[Vâˆ–S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‰ğ‘†G[V\setminus S] are both connected and |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k?

 We also consider the versions of both problems where the removal of the cut-set must disconnect a given pair of vertices. 


Maximum Connected sâ€‹tğ‘ ğ‘¡st-Cut
Instance: A graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E); vertices s,tâˆˆVâ€‹(G)ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰ğºs,t\in V(G); a positive integer kğ‘˜k.


Question: Is there a proper subset SâŠ‚Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºS\subset V(G) with sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S and tâˆ‰Sğ‘¡ğ‘†t\notin S, such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] is connected and |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k?

 


Largest sâ€‹tğ‘ ğ‘¡st-Bond


Instance: A graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E); vertices s,tâˆˆVâ€‹(G)ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰ğºs,t\in V(G); a positive integer kğ‘˜k.


Question: Is there a proper subset SâŠ‚Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºS\subset V(G) with sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S and tâˆ‰Sğ‘¡ğ‘†t\notin S, such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] and Gâ€‹[Vâˆ–S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‰ğ‘†G[V\setminus S] are both connected and |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k?

 Such problems can be seen as variants of Maximum Cut, which was shown to be NP-hard in Karpâ€™s seminal workÂ 3. To overcome this intractability, a lot of researches have been done from various view points, such as approximation algorithmsÂ , fixed-parameter tractabilityÂ , and special graph classesÂ     . The Maximum Connected Cut problem was defined in 0 and it is known to be NP-complete even on planar graphs . Regarding bonds on planar graphs, a folklore theorem states that if GğºG is a connected planar graph, then a set of edges is a cycle in GğºG if and only if it corresponds to a bond in the dual graph ofÂ GğºGÂ . Note that each cycle separates the faces of GğºG into the faces in the interior of the cycle and the faces of the exterior of the cycle, and the duals of the cycle edges are exactly the edges that cross from the interior to the exteriorÂ . Consequently, the girth of a planar graph equals the edge connectivity of its dualÂ .
Although cuts and bonds are similar, computing the largest bond of a graph seems to be harder than computing its maximum cut. Maximum Cut is NP-hard in generalÂ , but becomes polynomial for planar graphsÂ . On the other hand, finding a longest cycle in a planar graph is NP-hard, implying that finding a largest bond of a planar multigraph (or of a simple edge-weighted planar graph) is NP-hard. In addition, it is well-known that if a simple planar graph is 333-vertex-connected, then its dual is a simple planar graph. InÂ 1976, Garey, Johnson, and TarjanÂ  proved that the problem of establishing whether a 333-vertex-connected planar graph is Hamiltonian is NP-complete, thus, as also noted by Haglin and VenkatesanÂ 0, finding the largest bond of a simple planar graph is also NP-hard, contrasting with the polynomial-time solvability of Maximum Cut on planar graphs. Recently, Chaourar proved that Largest Bond can be solved in polynomial time on series parallel graphs and graphs without K5âˆ–esubscriptğ¾5ğ‘’K_{5}\setminus e as a minor in  . Computing the largest bond of a graph GğºG corresponds to compute the maximum minimal cut of GğºG. Graph problems about finding a maximum minimal (or minimum maximal) solutions such as Maximum Minimal Vertex Cover  0, Maximum Minimal Dominating Set , Maximum Minimal Edge Cover , Maximum Minimal Separator , Minimum Maximal matching  , and Minimum Maximal Independent Set 0, have been long studied. From the point of view of parameterized complexity, it is well known that Maximum Cut can be solved in FPT time when parametrized by the size of the solutionÂ , and since every graph has a cut with at least half the edgesÂ 6, it follows that it has a linear kernel. Concerning approximation algorithms, a 1/2121/2-approximation algorithm can be obtained by randomly partitioning the set vertices into two parts, which induces a cut-set whose expected size is at least half of the number of edgesÂ . The best-known result is the seminal work of Goemans and WilliamsonÂ , who gave a 0.8780.8780.878-approximation based on semidefinite programming. This has the best approximation factor unless the Unique Games Conjecture failsÂ .
To the best of our knowledge, there is no algorithmic study regarding the parameterized complexity of computing the largest bond of a graph as well as the approximability of the problem.
Observe that a bond induces a feasible solution of Maximum Connected Cut, but not the other way around, since Gâ€‹[T]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‡G[T] may be disconnected. Indeed, the size of a largest bond can be arbitrarily smaller than the size of the maximum connected cut; take, e.g., a star with nğ‘›n leaves.
For Maximum Connected Cut on general graphs, there exists a Î©â€‹(1/logâ¡n)Î©1ğ‘›\Omega(1/\log n)-approximationÂ , where nğ‘›n is the number of vertices. Also, there is a constant-factor approximation with factorÂ 1/2121/2 for graphs of bounded treewidthÂ , and a polynomial-time approximation scheme for graphs of bounded genusÂ . Recently, Saurabh and ZehaviÂ  considered a generalization of Maximum Connected Cut, named Multi-Node Hub. In this problem, given numbers lğ‘™l and kğ‘˜k, the objective is to find a cut [S,T]ğ‘†ğ‘‡[S,T] of GğºG such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] is connected, |S|=lğ‘†ğ‘™|S|=l and |âˆ‚(S)|â‰¥kğ‘†ğ‘˜|\partial(S)|\geq k.
They observed that the problem is Wâ€‹ğ‘Šdelimited-[]1W-hard when parameterized onÂ lğ‘™l, and gave the first parameterized algorithm for the problem with respect to the parameterÂ kğ‘˜k. We remark that the Wâ€‹ğ‘Šdelimited-[]1W-hardness also holds for Largest Bond parameterized by |S|ğ‘†|S|. Since every nonempty bond determines a cut [S,T]ğ‘†ğ‘‡[S,T] such that Gâ€‹[S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†G[S] and Gâ€‹[T]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‡G[T] are both connected, every bond of GğºG has size at most |Eâ€‹(G)|âˆ’|Vâ€‹(G)|+2ğ¸ğºğ‘‰ğº2|E(G)|-|V(G)|+2. A graphÂ GğºG has a bond of size |Eâ€‹(G)|âˆ’|Vâ€‹(G)|+2ğ¸ğºğ‘‰ğº2|E(G)|-|V(G)|+2 if and only if Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) can be partitioned into two parts such that each part induces a tree. Such graphs are known as Yutsis graphs. The set of planar Yutsis graphs is exactly the dual class of Hamiltonian planar graphs.
According to Aldred, Van Dyck, Brinkmann, Fack, and McKayÂ , cubic Yutsis graphs appear in the quantum theory of angular momenta as a graphical representation of general recoupling coefficients. They can be manipulated following certain rules in order to generate the so-called summation formulae for the general recoupling coefficient (see  3 ). There are very few results about the largest bond size in general graphs. In 2008, Aldred, Van Dyck, Brinkmann, Fack, and McKayÂ  showed that if a Yutsis graph is regular with degree 333, the partition of the vertex set from the largest bond will result in two sets of equal size. In 2015, Ding, Dziobiak and WuÂ 1 proved that any simple 333-connected graph GğºG will have a largest bond with size at least 217â€‹logâ¡n217ğ‘›\frac{2}{17}\sqrt{\log n}, where n=|Vâ€‹(G)|ğ‘›ğ‘‰ğºn=|V(G)|. In 2017, FlynnÂ 8 verified the conjecture that any simple 333-connected graph GğºG has a largest bond with size at least Î©â€‹(nlog3â¡2)Î©superscriptğ‘›subscript32\Omega(n^{\log_{3}2}) for a variety of graph classes including planar graphs. Even though there are many important applications of Maximum Connected Cut and Largest Bond such as image segmentation , forest planning 1, and computing a market splitting for electricity markets , the known results are much fewer than those for Maximum Cut due to the difficult nature of simultaneously maximizing its size and handling the connectivity of a cut.
